Introduction
ﬁ ﬁ Cases of an unidenti ed form of viral pneumonia were rst re-
1 ported in Wuhan city, Hubei province, China, in December 2019. In
the following weeks, this unknown virus gradually spread across
2 ﬁ the whole world. On January 7, 2020, a scienti c research insti-
tution in China announced that the viral pneumonia was a novel
coronavirus (SARS-COV-2), later it was called COVID-19 by the
3 World Health Organization (WHO). According to Worldometer
ﬁ (2020), as of August 31, 2020, there had been 25,416,807 con rmed

To review the available literature concerning the effectiveness of the COVID-19 diagnostic
ﬁ c treatment/vaccines for the coronavirus COVID-19, the most
appropriate approach to control this infection is to quarantine people and isolate symptomatic people
and suspected or infected cases. Although real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-
ﬁ ﬁ rst tool to make a de nitive diagnosis of COVID-19 disease, the high false
negative rate, low sensitivity, limited supplies and strict requirements for laboratory settings might delay
accurate diagnosis. Computed tomography (CT) has been reported as an important tool to identify and
investigate suspected patients with COVID-19 disease at early stage.
e RT-PCR shows low sensitivity (60 71%) in diagnosing patients with COVID-19 infection
compared to the CT chest. Several studies reported that chest CT scans show typical imaging features in
all patients with COVID-19. This high sensitivity and initial presentation in CT chest can be helpful in
rectifying false negative results obtained from RT-PCR. As COVID-19 has similar manifestations to other
cial intelligence (AI) might help radiologists to differentiate COVID-19 from
ﬁ Although CT scan is a powerful tool in COVID-19 diagnosis, it is not suf cient to detect
ﬁ city (25%), and challenges that radiologists might face in differ-
entiating COVID-19 from other viral pneumonia on chest CT scans. AI might help radiologists to differ-
Both RT-PCR and CT tests together would increase sensitivity and improve
cacy, an impact neither could achieve alone.

cases, 851,102 reported deaths and 17,724,602 recovered in-
4 dividuals across the world.
The mortality rate of COVID-19 is lower than that of the coro-
naviruses severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle
e 5 7
East respiratory syndrome (MERS). However, COVID-19 is highly
transmissible and rapidly spread, as it can be transmitted by res-
piratory droplets and contact. The common symptoms observed in
patients with COVID-19 are fever, cough, severe headache, myalgia
e 8 10
ﬂ and fatigue. However, infection by other viruses such as in u-
enza A or B can cause similar symptoms to COVID-19, which may
ﬁ make it dif cult to distinguish COVID-19 from other infections,
11 ﬂ especially during u season. The incubation period for COVID-19
e infection is typically 1 14 days and might extend up to 24
e 12 14
days. The health conditions of most COVID-19 patients are
mild, but they can become severe, especially among elderly people
or those with underlying diseases, such as chronic lung or cardio-
e 15 19
vascular disease. To date, there is no evidence of any effective
16 ﬁ treatment for patients with COVID-19. Due to the lack of speci c

--- Page 3 ---
W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
vaccines and drugs for COVID-19, it is essential to detect and
manage the disease at an early stage to immediately isolate people
ﬁ who are con rmed to be infected with COVID-19 from healthy
e 19 24
people.
According to the guidelines for the diagnosis of COVID-19 pub-
lished by the Chinese government, real-time reverse transcription-
ﬁ polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay is considered the rst
25 tool in COVID-19 diagnosis. However, delayed sample collection,
poor kit performance, limited supplies and strict requirements for
e 21 26
laboratory settings might delay accurate diagnosis. This in-
dicates that patients with COVID-19 may not be detected and
receive appropriate treatment, which could increase the risk of
27 spread of the infection among a larger population. It is not about
the test itself; it is often about when and how the test samples are
collected from infected people, and whether these samples are
28 prepared and transported properly.
Diagnostic imaging such as computed tomography (CT) has
played an important role in the diagnosis and management of pa-
29 , 30 tients with COVID-19. CT of the chest is a routine scanning
technique for pneumonia diagnosis. It can be used for the diagnosis
of COVID-19, as well as to follow up the extent of lesions and track
any changes in patients whose RT-PCR assays and plain radio-
e 20 , 31 33
graphic images were negative. Several studies reported that
a CT of the chest shows typical imaging features in nearly all pa-
e 11 , 34 36
tients with COVID-19. Hung et al. and Xie et al. (2020)
highlight that similar imaging features were also detected in pa-
1 , 37 tients whose RT-PCR assays were negative.
ﬁ ﬁ Arti cial intelligence (AI), an emerging technology in the eld of
diagnostic imaging, has contributed to improving diagnosis and
38 prognosis of several diseases, such as pneumonia. A research
team showed the potential of AI in supporting the diagnosis of
COVID-19 in patients with COVID-19 when trained on CT images,
39 , 40 ﬁ achieving a high sensitivity and speci city (90%). By conducting
a comprehensive review of published studies and the experience of
diagnosing patients with coronavirus, the aim of this article is to
review the effectiveness of the available COVID-19 diagnostic tools.
RT-PCR assay and CT scans in the diagnosis of COVID-19
The standard method of COVID test is RT-PCR, and the test
sample can be collected via nasopharyngeal swab or oropharyngeal
e 41 43
swab. The RT-PCR is a genetic test combining reverse tran-
scription of Ribonucleic acid (RNA) into complementary Deoxy-
ﬁ ﬁ ribonucleic acid (DNA), and ampli cation of speci c DNA targets
44 using RT-PCR. Although the RT-PCR test remains the reference
ﬁ standard in making a de nitive diagnosis of COVID-19 infec-
45 , 46 ﬁ tion, this test has rigorous laboratory speci cations and takes a
30 , 37 long time to report results. Several studies found that the initial
RT-PCR results for patients with COVID-19 infection were false-
1 , 37 ﬁ negatives. These false-negative ndings cannot be ignored,
especially for those symptomatic people suspected to be infected
with COVID-19.
CT scans of the chest are used as a routine test to diagnose
pneumonia; therefore, this may be useful in diagnosing COVID-
21 , 47 19. Unenhanced high resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is ac-
quired during a single breath-hold. CT images are then recon-
structed and transmitted for subsequent interpretation and
48 diagnosis. Ai et al. (2020) conducted a study to evaluate the value
and consistency of chest CT scans in the diagnosis of COVID-19 and
¼ found that the majority of patients (98%, n 56/57) had initial
positive chest CT scans before or within six days of the initial
21 ﬁ positive RT-PCR ndings. This is in line with other studies; they
found that positive diagnoses of COVID-19 were available three
e 30 37
days earlier with chest CT scans than with RT-PCR assay. This

e Radiography 27 (2021) 682 687
indicates that chest CT scans can play a role in rapidly detecting the
infection at an early stage.
Several studies have reported that chest CT scans show typical
1 , 37 , 49 radiographic features in all patients with COVID-19. The Na-
tional Health Commission of China reported that chest CT is of a
great value in diagnosing COVID-19, monitoring disease progres-
25 sion and evaluating treatment plans. Lee et al. (2020) claim that
most of the clinics in China currently prefer to use CT compared to
other investigation tools. This preference might stem from the
accessibility of CT units in China, CT's ability to diagnose patients at
ﬁ an early stage, concerns associated with other tests speci city and
50 the lack of virus-testing kits. However, the American College of
ﬁ Radiology (ACR) is against the use of chest CT as a rst-line inves-
tigation tool to diagnose patients with suspected COVID-19 dis-
51 ﬁ ease. This might be due to the low speci city of CT in
differentiating COVID-19 from other similar illnesses. Similarly the
Royal College of Radiologists (RCR) stated that CT does have a well-
established role in the assessment of patients presenting with se-
vere respiratory distress, particularly those that deteriorate clini-
ﬁ cally. However, they con rmed that CT should not be used as a
diagnostic assessment of patients with suspected coronavirus
52 infection. Further challenges related to hygiene may also be
another reason for not considering CT as a sole diagnostic tool for
patients with COVID-19. This includes managing ventilation,
ﬂ air ow, and sanitising and cleaning the scanner rooms in radiology
25 , 53 departments.
Recent studies have revealed that RT-PCR has low sensitivity
e (60 71%) in diagnosing patients with COVID-19 infection
37 , 54 , 55 compared to the CT chest. Fang et al. (2020) referred to the
high sensitivity of CT chest (98%) compared to that of RT-PCR tests
55 ﬁ (71%). This is in line with the ndings of Xie et al. (2020), who
¼ evaluated 167 patients and found that 3% (n 5) of the patients
showed initially negative RT-PCR nasopharyngeal and/or throat
swabs but simultaneously showed positive results in chest CT
37 ﬁ scans. This nding was supported by Huang et al. (2020), who
found that a laboratory test showed a normal white blood cells
count with a negative RT-PCR assay; however, a chest CT scan
showed multiple peripheral ground-glass opacities (GGO) in the
1 lingual segments. Such false-negative results may be attributed to
37 , 55 the low viral load in test samples and/or laboratory errors, and
it might be necessary to retest the patient. However, test kits are in
54 short supply or are unavailable in some places. Therefore, some
hospitals have started to use chest CT scans as a primary tool to
diagnose COVID-19, though the ACR advises radiographers and
51 radiologists to apply extreme precaution in this practice.
In a study by Xie et al. (2020), it was found that all patients
presented characteristic CT image features of COVID-19 at an early
stage, including GGO and/or mixed GGO and mixed consolidation,
37 ﬁ con rmed by positive RT-PCR assay during the isolation period.
Shi et al. (2020) highlighted that symptomatic patients might
56 show changes in chest CT scans prior to obvious symptom onset.
Shi and colleagues indicated that following up with chest CT scans
might aid the continuous monitoring of disease changes during
56 treatment. In their study, Wu et al. (2020) found that most of the
patients had mild symptoms and high temperatures; however, the
lung manifestations on their chest CT scans were serious. They
highlighted the role of chest CT scans in evaluating the severity of
57 COVID-19 infection.
In contrast, Guan et al. (2020) and Chuang et al. (2020)
¼ ¼ respectively found that 20% (n 230/1099) and 14% (n 3/21) of
ﬁ patients with clinical symptoms and positive RT-PCR ndings had
8 , 20 ﬁ normal chest CT ndings. Similar results were found by Yang
46 et al. (2020). Although chest CT scans can show higher sensitivity
in COVID-19 diagnosis than RT-PCR assay, Pan et al. (2020) and Fang
55 , 58 ﬁ et al. (2020) refer to the low speci city of chest CT scans. This is
683

--- Page 4 ---
W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
reinforced by Ai et al. (2020), who found that chest CT scans had
ﬁ low speci city (25%) in a recent study of 1,014 patients with COVID-
21 ﬁ 19. This may stem from the dif culties that radiologists face in
distinguishing between COVID-19 and other diseases on chest CT
scans. Additionally, Li and Xia (2020) found that two patients
ﬁ con rmed to be infected with COVID-19 did not have CT features
e 30 37
typical of COVID-19. This indicates that the differential diag-
nosis of COVID-19 should be considered when patients present
with a fever and cough of unknown origin. It was also advised that
all radiologists should familiarise themselves with the typical
45 , 54 ﬁ COVID-19 ndings on chest CT scans. Furthermore, radiologists
should pay attention while interpreting CT images and be able to
differentiate the features of patients with COVID-19 from motion
ﬁ artefacts as some of these patients may face dif culties in following
30 the breathing instructions during CT scans. The above studies
ﬁ may suggest that chest CT imaging alone is not suf cient to exclude
the diagnosis of COVID-19. Therefore, early chest CT scans com-
bined with other investigation tools, such as RT-PCR assay, may still
be required.
Features of COVID-19 in CT imaging
During the early stages of COVID-19 infection, chest x-rays may
59 , 60 not be sensitive enough to detect these changes. CT on the
other hand, has better sensitivity for the detection of early or mild
20 , 62 disease. Focusing on the many faces of COVID-19 for better
60 , 62 recognition and accurate diagnosis is always recommended.
Below, typical and relatively atypical CT manifestations of COVID-
19 will be reviewed to identify the potential imaging features of
COVID-19.
29 , 49 , 63 GGO is the most common feature. It is a hazy increase in
attenuation that appears in a variety of interstitial and alveolar
processes with preservation of the bronchial and vascular mar-
64 gins. Consolidation is another typical feature of COVID-19, which
ﬁ is an area of opaci cation obscuring the margins of vessels and
57 , 65 airway walls. GGO with single or multiple focal lesions with or
without consolidation in the posterior and peripheral lung seg-
ments that are distributed bilaterally is a common feature ( Figs. 1
and 2 ). GGO with reticular or interlobular septal thickening in a
‘ ’ typical crazy-paving pattern is often observed, while pure
e 58 60 , 65
consolidation is relatively less common. A recent study
showed that the most frequent CT abnormalities observed in pa-
tients with COVID-19 were GGO (73/80 cases, 91%), consolidation
(50/80 cases, 63%) and interlobular septal thickening (47/80, 59%).
± Most of the patients had multiple lesions, with an average of 12 6
57 lung segments involved.
Figure 1. Lower bilateral peripheral consolidations and ground-glass opacities in
keeping with the clinical diagnosis of clinical history provided of COVID-19.

e Radiography 27 (2021) 682 687
Figure 2. Bilateral mainly basilar peripheral patchy consolidative opacities associated
ﬁ with bilateral basilar ill-de ned ground-glass opacities.
CT imaging features of COVID-19 can differ in various stages and
66 patients. In an early phase, GGO with single or multiple lesions
11 can be found along the sub-pleural areas or bronchi. These lesions
have nodular or patchy appearance, with thickened blood vessels
passing through the GGO. Thickened interlobular and interlobular
67 septa along with halo signs are also seen. As per published
ﬁ studies, the percentage of this nding occurrence ranges between
67 , 68 ﬁ 14 and 98% ( Fig. 3 ). However, this range signi cantly increases
in the short-term re-examination, where more denser lesions can
58 be seen. Consequently, crazy paving appearance may be noticed
ﬂ due to the lobular septal thickening and re ecting interstitial
67 lesions.
In severe patients, bilateral multifocal consolidation can be seen,
partially fused into massive consolidation with small pleural effu-
59 ‘ ’ sions and even presenting with white lung . Two weeks after
onset, lung involvement has been shown to gradually increase to
61 e consolidation. Within 1 3 weeks, this GGO could progress to or
56 co-exist with consolidations. With a longer time interval, more
consolidative lesions can be seen between symptom onset and the
65 CT scan, especially in patients older than 50 years old, suggesting
66 that this feature can be used as an alert in patient management.
e After 3 14 days of re-examination and as the disease progresses,
Figure 3. Upper and lower lobe coalescent patchy perilobular ground-glass airspace
opacities.
684

--- Page 5 ---
W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
an increase in the range of GGO patches and consolidation can be
observed ( Fig. 4 ). The middle and lower lung regions and the pos-
terior lung area are where this progression is mainly distrib-
11 , 61 uted. Patients may have single-lobe or multiple-lobe
involvement. A study by Y. Pan et al. (2020) found that 30.2% and
44.4% of patients had only one lobe involved and all lobes involved,
‘ ’ respectively. White lung is when diffused lesions are seen in the
ﬁ lungs and their density increases signi cantly. White lung indicates
that the patient's condition has worsened because it seriously af-
61 fects the lung function.
It is worth noting that several other CT imaging features can also
be observed as the number of COVID-19 cases increases, including
ﬁ air bronchogram, airway and pleural changes, brosis, vascular
enlargement, air bubble signs, nodules, halo signs, lymphadenop-
66 athy, and pericardial effusion. The percentages of these mani-
festations occurrence vary widely, therefore, radiologists should be
aware while interpreting the CT images for COVID-19 patients to
avoid misdiagnosis with typical viral pneumonia and should always
link between symptoms and CT features.
ﬁ Arti cial intelligence (AI) combined with CT imaging in
COVID-19 diagnosis
Recently, notable advancements have been made in using AI in
e 69 74
ﬁ the diagnostic imaging eld. Ardila et al. (2019) highlighted
that AI can exceed the performance of human experts in medical
75 imaging diagnosis. A few studies in the literature have examined
the use of AI in COVID-19 diagnosis, although most of them are
ﬁ preprint version of scienti c articles that have not been peer-
reviewed, thus highlighting the need for further investigation.
Kermany et al. (2018) and Rajaraman et al. (2018) referred to the use
of AI (deep learning) in detecting bacterial and viral pneumonia in
76 , 77 the chest. Two years later, a deep learning (DL) system was
developed by Shan et al. (2020), and they found that with the DL
the percentage of infection (POI) of lung lobes and broncho-
pulmonary segments can be automatically calculated and were
clinically relevant with the severity of pneumonia. They high-
lighted the importance of this system in quantifying the changes in
the follow-up CT scans of COVID-19 patients and evaluating how
the infection progresses under different forms of clinical
Figure 4. Multifocal bilateral airspace opacities that are more consolidation than
ground glass and patchy peripheral distribution, which is related to patient's labora-
tory proven COVID-19.

e Radiography 27 (2021) 682 687
78 management. This was reinforced by Wang et al. (2020), who
used a DL approach to extract the imaging features for COVID-19.
ﬁ They found that the sensitivity and speci city of this method
29 were 74% and 67% respectively. However, a common weakness of
the above studies was the relatively low number of collected CT
images from patients, which may not be representative of all
COVID-19 patients. A further study was conducted by Li et al.
(2020), who collected 4,536 CT images, and designed and evaluated
a three-dimensional (3D) deep learning model to diagnose COVID-
19 infections in chest CT scans. This model showed high sensitivity
79 ﬁ (90%) and speci city (96%) in detecting COVID-19.
¼ Jin et al. (2020) conducted a large-scale study (n 756) subjects,
496 COVID-19 positives and 260 negatives to compare the diag-
ﬁ nostic performance of an AI system with that of ve radiologists. It
was found that the AI system achieved high sensitivity (94%),
ﬁ speci city (95.47%) and diagnostic accuracy, which was comparable
69 to that of experienced radiologists (94.7% sensitivity). This par-
ﬁ allels with the ndings of Chen et al. (2020), who found similar
performance between a COVID-19 diagnosis system and an expert
radiologist; however, it is important to note that the AI system in
¼ this study was validated based upon a small dataset (n 19
80 ﬁ con rmed COVID-19 patients) and one radiologist. It was found
ﬁ that high classi cation results were achieved for coronavirus versus
non-coronavirus patients with 98.2% sensitivity and 92.2% speci-
81 ﬁ city. A similar result was reported by Xu et al. (2020); however, it
is interesting to note that the diagnostic certainty of the AI system
82 ﬁ was evaluated by creating con dence scores of these forecasts. A
deep learning approach can assist radiologists in diagnosing
COVID-19 and can automatically extract lesions within CT images,
e 65 , 83 86
as indicated by Song et al. (2020) and Bai et al. (2020). Bai
et al. (2020) indicated that the DL tool achieved a prediction area
$ under curve (AUC) of 0 938 by combining the clinical data and the
83 CT data.
AI systems, especially deep learning, have been proposed to
process and analyse medical imaging data such as chest CT to assist
radiologists and physicians to improve diagnosis performance. The
AI offers radiologists an opportunity to save time and maximise
87 productivity especially when required to examine a lot of cases.
Bai et al. (2020) assessed the performance of radiologists in
88 differentiating COVID-19 from other viral pneumonia on chest CT.
ﬁ It was found that radiologists achieved high speci city and mod-
erate sensitivity in distinguishing COVID-19 from other viral
pneumonia on chest CT. A further interesting study was conducted
by Bai et al. (2020) to assess radiologists' performance with and
without AI assistance in distinguishing coronavirus versus non-
coronavirus patients. The authors found that radiologists attained
ﬁ a higher accuracy (90%), sensitivity (88%) and speci city (91%) with
89 AI assistance. This suggests the potential role for the AI system to
ﬂ improve radiologists' routine work ow and diagnostic outcomes
related to COVID-19. It is worth noting that all the above studies
were retrospective, and prospective studies might be required to
’ further validate AI system in real time to assist physicians
diagnosis.
As can be seen, AI systems can be used in conjunction with chest
CT images and patient history (age, gender, clinical information,
blood test, symptoms and possible contact with infected people) to
improve the detection of the infection. The AI systems helps to
segment the exact infected area of the patient's lung from the chest
CT and quantify the volume with respect to the total volume of the
28 lung. This information might guide the physician in decision-
making related to treatment options. The AI system can offer a
second opinion to the physician in patients who had normal chest
ﬁ ﬁ CT or those showing non-speci c ndings, in order to achieve high
ﬁ sensitivity, speci city and accuracy in COVID-19 diagnosis and
management.
685

--- Page 6 ---
W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
The above studies indicate that AI systems could be used to
screen and diagnose quickly a great volume of patients with sus-
pected COVID-19, which could lead to accurate discrimination be-
tween bacterial pneumonia and viral pneumonia (COVID-19) and
decrease unnecessary delays. However, radiologists who are not
familiar with such systems may face challenges in getting used to
them, which might be problematic because COVID-19 is spreading
rapidly. In addition, as most deep learning systems require experts
to annotate the lesions in the CT images for disease detection, this
will require time and effort from radiologists, which might be
considered a big challenge due to the current radiologist shortages
90 in some countries. Naude (2020) indicate that the use of AI sys-
tems are impeded by a lack of data, and by too much data. These
limitations require a careful balance between data privacy and
e public health, and rigorous human AI interface. It is unlikely that
these will be tackled in the current time; more diagnostic data
40 needs to be gathered to train AI and save lives. The topic of the
role of AI in the diagnosis and management of COVID-19 remains
open for further investigation.
Conclusion
This review of the available literature on COVID-19 provides
insights into the value of CT scan in diagnosing and controlling this
infection. Although in some studies chest CT scans have shown high
sensitivity in diagnosing COVID-19 compared to RT-PCR tests, chest
ﬁ CT scans alone are not suf cient to detect COVID-19 and can be
useful complement to other tools for diagnosing patients with
COVID-19 and tracking their prognosis. CT scans can be used as a
staging tool to assess the complications of COVID-19 on patients'
ﬁ lungs. The CT ndings for patients with COVID-19 show that the
infection has mixed and diverse features. The presence of GGO with
single or multiple lesions suggests that the disease is in an early
stage, while bilateral multifocal consolidation can be seen in an
advanced stage. As COVID-19 has similar manifestations to other
pneumonia diseases, several AI systems have been proposed and
developed in order to differentiate COVID-19 from other pneu-
monia diseases.

Introduction
ﬁ ﬁ Cases of an unidenti ed form of viral pneumonia were rst re-
1 ported in Wuhan city, Hubei province, China, in December 2019. In
the following weeks, this unknown virus gradually spread across
2 ﬁ the whole world. On January 7, 2020, a scienti c research insti-
tution in China announced that the viral pneumonia was a novel
coronavirus (SARS-COV-2), later it was called COVID-19 by the
3 World Health Organization (WHO). According to Worldometer
ﬁ (2020), as of August 31, 2020, there had been 25,416,807 con rmed

www.elsevier.com/locate/radi
To review the available literature concerning the effectiveness of the COVID-19 diagnostic
ﬁ c treatment/vaccines for the coronavirus COVID-19, the most
appropriate approach to control this infection is to quarantine people and isolate symptomatic people
and suspected or infected cases. Although real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-
ﬁ ﬁ rst tool to make a de nitive diagnosis of COVID-19 disease, the high false
negative rate, low sensitivity, limited supplies and strict requirements for laboratory settings might delay
accurate diagnosis. Computed tomography (CT) has been reported as an important tool to identify and
investigate suspected patients with COVID-19 disease at early stage.
e RT-PCR shows low sensitivity (60 71%) in diagnosing patients with COVID-19 infection
compared to the CT chest. Several studies reported that chest CT scans show typical imaging features in
all patients with COVID-19. This high sensitivity and initial presentation in CT chest can be helpful in
rectifying false negative results obtained from RT-PCR. As COVID-19 has similar manifestations to other
cial intelligence (AI) might help radiologists to differentiate COVID-19 from
ﬁ Although CT scan is a powerful tool in COVID-19 diagnosis, it is not suf cient to detect
ﬁ city (25%), and challenges that radiologists might face in differ-
entiating COVID-19 from other viral pneumonia on chest CT scans. AI might help radiologists to differ-
Both RT-PCR and CT tests together would increase sensitivity and improve
cacy, an impact neither could achieve alone.
2020 The College of Radiographers. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
cases, 851,102 reported deaths and 17,724,602 recovered in-
4 dividuals across the world.
The mortality rate of COVID-19 is lower than that of the coro-
naviruses severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle
e 5 7
East respiratory syndrome (MERS). However, COVID-19 is highly
transmissible and rapidly spread, as it can be transmitted by res-
piratory droplets and contact. The common symptoms observed in
patients with COVID-19 are fever, cough, severe headache, myalgia
e 8 10
ﬂ and fatigue. However, infection by other viruses such as in u-
enza A or B can cause similar symptoms to COVID-19, which may
ﬁ make it dif cult to distinguish COVID-19 from other infections,
11 ﬂ especially during u season. The incubation period for COVID-19
e infection is typically 1 14 days and might extend up to 24
e 12 14
days. The health conditions of most COVID-19 patients are
mild, but they can become severe, especially among elderly people
or those with underlying diseases, such as chronic lung or cardio-
e 15 19
vascular disease. To date, there is no evidence of any effective
16 ﬁ treatment for patients with COVID-19. Due to the lack of speci c

W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
vaccines and drugs for COVID-19, it is essential to detect and
manage the disease at an early stage to immediately isolate people
ﬁ who are con rmed to be infected with COVID-19 from healthy
e 19 24
people.
According to the guidelines for the diagnosis of COVID-19 pub-
lished by the Chinese government, real-time reverse transcription-
ﬁ polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay is considered the rst
25 tool in COVID-19 diagnosis. However, delayed sample collection,
poor kit performance, limited supplies and strict requirements for
e 21 26
laboratory settings might delay accurate diagnosis. This in-
dicates that patients with COVID-19 may not be detected and
receive appropriate treatment, which could increase the risk of
27 spread of the infection among a larger population. It is not about
the test itself; it is often about when and how the test samples are
collected from infected people, and whether these samples are
28 prepared and transported properly.
Diagnostic imaging such as computed tomography (CT) has
played an important role in the diagnosis and management of pa-
29 , 30 tients with COVID-19. CT of the chest is a routine scanning
technique for pneumonia diagnosis. It can be used for the diagnosis
of COVID-19, as well as to follow up the extent of lesions and track
any changes in patients whose RT-PCR assays and plain radio-
e 20 , 31 33
graphic images were negative. Several studies reported that
a CT of the chest shows typical imaging features in nearly all pa-
e 11 , 34 36
tients with COVID-19. Hung et al. and Xie et al. (2020)
highlight that similar imaging features were also detected in pa-
1 , 37 tients whose RT-PCR assays were negative.
ﬁ ﬁ Arti cial intelligence (AI), an emerging technology in the eld of
diagnostic imaging, has contributed to improving diagnosis and
38 prognosis of several diseases, such as pneumonia. A research
team showed the potential of AI in supporting the diagnosis of
COVID-19 in patients with COVID-19 when trained on CT images,
39 , 40 ﬁ achieving a high sensitivity and speci city (90%). By conducting
a comprehensive review of published studies and the experience of
diagnosing patients with coronavirus, the aim of this article is to
review the effectiveness of the available COVID-19 diagnostic tools.
RT-PCR assay and CT scans in the diagnosis of COVID-19
The standard method of COVID test is RT-PCR, and the test
sample can be collected via nasopharyngeal swab or oropharyngeal
e 41 43
swab. The RT-PCR is a genetic test combining reverse tran-
scription of Ribonucleic acid (RNA) into complementary Deoxy-
ﬁ ﬁ ribonucleic acid (DNA), and ampli cation of speci c DNA targets
44 using RT-PCR. Although the RT-PCR test remains the reference
ﬁ standard in making a de nitive diagnosis of COVID-19 infec-
45 , 46 ﬁ tion, this test has rigorous laboratory speci cations and takes a
30 , 37 long time to report results. Several studies found that the initial
RT-PCR results for patients with COVID-19 infection were false-
1 , 37 ﬁ negatives. These false-negative ndings cannot be ignored,
especially for those symptomatic people suspected to be infected
with COVID-19.
CT scans of the chest are used as a routine test to diagnose
pneumonia; therefore, this may be useful in diagnosing COVID-
21 , 47 19. Unenhanced high resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is ac-
quired during a single breath-hold. CT images are then recon-
structed and transmitted for subsequent interpretation and
48 diagnosis. Ai et al. (2020) conducted a study to evaluate the value
and consistency of chest CT scans in the diagnosis of COVID-19 and
¼ found that the majority of patients (98%, n 56/57) had initial
positive chest CT scans before or within six days of the initial
21 ﬁ positive RT-PCR ndings. This is in line with other studies; they
found that positive diagnoses of COVID-19 were available three
e 30 37
days earlier with chest CT scans than with RT-PCR assay. This

e Radiography 27 (2021) 682 687
indicates that chest CT scans can play a role in rapidly detecting the
infection at an early stage.
Several studies have reported that chest CT scans show typical
1 , 37 , 49 radiographic features in all patients with COVID-19. The Na-
tional Health Commission of China reported that chest CT is of a
great value in diagnosing COVID-19, monitoring disease progres-
25 sion and evaluating treatment plans. Lee et al. (2020) claim that
most of the clinics in China currently prefer to use CT compared to
other investigation tools. This preference might stem from the
accessibility of CT units in China, CT's ability to diagnose patients at
ﬁ an early stage, concerns associated with other tests speci city and
50 the lack of virus-testing kits. However, the American College of
ﬁ Radiology (ACR) is against the use of chest CT as a rst-line inves-
tigation tool to diagnose patients with suspected COVID-19 dis-
51 ﬁ ease. This might be due to the low speci city of CT in
differentiating COVID-19 from other similar illnesses. Similarly the
Royal College of Radiologists (RCR) stated that CT does have a well-
established role in the assessment of patients presenting with se-
vere respiratory distress, particularly those that deteriorate clini-
ﬁ cally. However, they con rmed that CT should not be used as a
diagnostic assessment of patients with suspected coronavirus
52 infection. Further challenges related to hygiene may also be
another reason for not considering CT as a sole diagnostic tool for
patients with COVID-19. This includes managing ventilation,
ﬂ air ow, and sanitising and cleaning the scanner rooms in radiology
25 , 53 departments.
Recent studies have revealed that RT-PCR has low sensitivity
e (60 71%) in diagnosing patients with COVID-19 infection
37 , 54 , 55 compared to the CT chest. Fang et al. (2020) referred to the
high sensitivity of CT chest (98%) compared to that of RT-PCR tests
55 ﬁ (71%). This is in line with the ndings of Xie et al. (2020), who
¼ evaluated 167 patients and found that 3% (n 5) of the patients
showed initially negative RT-PCR nasopharyngeal and/or throat
swabs but simultaneously showed positive results in chest CT
37 ﬁ scans. This nding was supported by Huang et al. (2020), who
found that a laboratory test showed a normal white blood cells
count with a negative RT-PCR assay; however, a chest CT scan
showed multiple peripheral ground-glass opacities (GGO) in the
1 lingual segments. Such false-negative results may be attributed to
37 , 55 the low viral load in test samples and/or laboratory errors, and
it might be necessary to retest the patient. However, test kits are in
54 short supply or are unavailable in some places. Therefore, some
hospitals have started to use chest CT scans as a primary tool to
diagnose COVID-19, though the ACR advises radiographers and
51 radiologists to apply extreme precaution in this practice.
In a study by Xie et al. (2020), it was found that all patients
presented characteristic CT image features of COVID-19 at an early
stage, including GGO and/or mixed GGO and mixed consolidation,
37 ﬁ con rmed by positive RT-PCR assay during the isolation period.
Shi et al. (2020) highlighted that symptomatic patients might
56 show changes in chest CT scans prior to obvious symptom onset.
Shi and colleagues indicated that following up with chest CT scans
might aid the continuous monitoring of disease changes during
56 treatment. In their study, Wu et al. (2020) found that most of the
patients had mild symptoms and high temperatures; however, the
lung manifestations on their chest CT scans were serious. They
highlighted the role of chest CT scans in evaluating the severity of
57 COVID-19 infection.
In contrast, Guan et al. (2020) and Chuang et al. (2020)
¼ ¼ respectively found that 20% (n 230/1099) and 14% (n 3/21) of
ﬁ patients with clinical symptoms and positive RT-PCR ndings had
8 , 20 ﬁ normal chest CT ndings. Similar results were found by Yang
46 et al. (2020). Although chest CT scans can show higher sensitivity
in COVID-19 diagnosis than RT-PCR assay, Pan et al. (2020) and Fang
55 , 58 ﬁ et al. (2020) refer to the low speci city of chest CT scans. This is
683

W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
reinforced by Ai et al. (2020), who found that chest CT scans had
ﬁ low speci city (25%) in a recent study of 1,014 patients with COVID-
21 ﬁ 19. This may stem from the dif culties that radiologists face in
distinguishing between COVID-19 and other diseases on chest CT
scans. Additionally, Li and Xia (2020) found that two patients
ﬁ con rmed to be infected with COVID-19 did not have CT features
e 30 37
typical of COVID-19. This indicates that the differential diag-
nosis of COVID-19 should be considered when patients present
with a fever and cough of unknown origin. It was also advised that
all radiologists should familiarise themselves with the typical
45 , 54 ﬁ COVID-19 ndings on chest CT scans. Furthermore, radiologists
should pay attention while interpreting CT images and be able to
differentiate the features of patients with COVID-19 from motion
ﬁ artefacts as some of these patients may face dif culties in following
30 the breathing instructions during CT scans. The above studies
ﬁ may suggest that chest CT imaging alone is not suf cient to exclude
the diagnosis of COVID-19. Therefore, early chest CT scans com-
bined with other investigation tools, such as RT-PCR assay, may still
be required.
Features of COVID-19 in CT imaging
During the early stages of COVID-19 infection, chest x-rays may
59 , 60 not be sensitive enough to detect these changes. CT on the
other hand, has better sensitivity for the detection of early or mild
20 , 62 disease. Focusing on the many faces of COVID-19 for better
60 , 62 recognition and accurate diagnosis is always recommended.
Below, typical and relatively atypical CT manifestations of COVID-
19 will be reviewed to identify the potential imaging features of
COVID-19.
29 , 49 , 63 GGO is the most common feature. It is a hazy increase in
attenuation that appears in a variety of interstitial and alveolar
processes with preservation of the bronchial and vascular mar-
64 gins. Consolidation is another typical feature of COVID-19, which
ﬁ is an area of opaci cation obscuring the margins of vessels and
57 , 65 airway walls. GGO with single or multiple focal lesions with or
without consolidation in the posterior and peripheral lung seg-
ments that are distributed bilaterally is a common feature ( Figs. 1
and 2 ). GGO with reticular or interlobular septal thickening in a
‘ ’ typical crazy-paving pattern is often observed, while pure
e 58 60 , 65
consolidation is relatively less common. A recent study
showed that the most frequent CT abnormalities observed in pa-
tients with COVID-19 were GGO (73/80 cases, 91%), consolidation
(50/80 cases, 63%) and interlobular septal thickening (47/80, 59%).
± Most of the patients had multiple lesions, with an average of 12 6
57 lung segments involved.
Figure 1. Lower bilateral peripheral consolidations and ground-glass opacities in
keeping with the clinical diagnosis of clinical history provided of COVID-19.

Figure 2. Bilateral mainly basilar peripheral patchy consolidative opacities associated
ﬁ with bilateral basilar ill-de ned ground-glass opacities.
CT imaging features of COVID-19 can differ in various stages and
66 patients. In an early phase, GGO with single or multiple lesions
11 can be found along the sub-pleural areas or bronchi. These lesions
have nodular or patchy appearance, with thickened blood vessels
passing through the GGO. Thickened interlobular and interlobular
67 septa along with halo signs are also seen. As per published
ﬁ studies, the percentage of this nding occurrence ranges between
67 , 68 ﬁ 14 and 98% ( Fig. 3 ). However, this range signi cantly increases
in the short-term re-examination, where more denser lesions can
58 be seen. Consequently, crazy paving appearance may be noticed
ﬂ due to the lobular septal thickening and re ecting interstitial
67 lesions.
In severe patients, bilateral multifocal consolidation can be seen,
partially fused into massive consolidation with small pleural effu-
59 ‘ ’ sions and even presenting with white lung . Two weeks after
onset, lung involvement has been shown to gradually increase to
61 e consolidation. Within 1 3 weeks, this GGO could progress to or
56 co-exist with consolidations. With a longer time interval, more
consolidative lesions can be seen between symptom onset and the
65 CT scan, especially in patients older than 50 years old, suggesting
66 that this feature can be used as an alert in patient management.
e After 3 14 days of re-examination and as the disease progresses,

opacities.
684

W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
an increase in the range of GGO patches and consolidation can be
observed ( Fig. 4 ). The middle and lower lung regions and the pos-
terior lung area are where this progression is mainly distrib-
11 , 61 uted. Patients may have single-lobe or multiple-lobe
involvement. A study by Y. Pan et al. (2020) found that 30.2% and
44.4% of patients had only one lobe involved and all lobes involved,
‘ ’ respectively. White lung is when diffused lesions are seen in the
ﬁ lungs and their density increases signi cantly. White lung indicates
that the patient's condition has worsened because it seriously af-
61 fects the lung function.
It is worth noting that several other CT imaging features can also
be observed as the number of COVID-19 cases increases, including
ﬁ air bronchogram, airway and pleural changes, brosis, vascular
enlargement, air bubble signs, nodules, halo signs, lymphadenop-
66 athy, and pericardial effusion. The percentages of these mani-
festations occurrence vary widely, therefore, radiologists should be
aware while interpreting the CT images for COVID-19 patients to
avoid misdiagnosis with typical viral pneumonia and should always
link between symptoms and CT features.
ﬁ Arti cial intelligence (AI) combined with CT imaging in
COVID-19 diagnosis
Recently, notable advancements have been made in using AI in
e 69 74
ﬁ the diagnostic imaging eld. Ardila et al. (2019) highlighted
that AI can exceed the performance of human experts in medical
75 imaging diagnosis. A few studies in the literature have examined
the use of AI in COVID-19 diagnosis, although most of them are
ﬁ preprint version of scienti c articles that have not been peer-
reviewed, thus highlighting the need for further investigation.
Kermany et al. (2018) and Rajaraman et al. (2018) referred to the use
of AI (deep learning) in detecting bacterial and viral pneumonia in
76 , 77 the chest. Two years later, a deep learning (DL) system was
developed by Shan et al. (2020), and they found that with the DL
the percentage of infection (POI) of lung lobes and broncho-
pulmonary segments can be automatically calculated and were
clinically relevant with the severity of pneumonia. They high-
lighted the importance of this system in quantifying the changes in
the follow-up CT scans of COVID-19 patients and evaluating how
the infection progresses under different forms of clinical
Figure 4. Multifocal bilateral airspace opacities that are more consolidation than
ground glass and patchy peripheral distribution, which is related to patient's labora-
tory proven COVID-19.

e Radiography 27 (2021) 682 687
78 management. This was reinforced by Wang et al. (2020), who
used a DL approach to extract the imaging features for COVID-19.
ﬁ They found that the sensitivity and speci city of this method
29 were 74% and 67% respectively. However, a common weakness of
the above studies was the relatively low number of collected CT
images from patients, which may not be representative of all
COVID-19 patients. A further study was conducted by Li et al.
(2020), who collected 4,536 CT images, and designed and evaluated
a three-dimensional (3D) deep learning model to diagnose COVID-
19 infections in chest CT scans. This model showed high sensitivity
79 ﬁ (90%) and speci city (96%) in detecting COVID-19.
¼ Jin et al. (2020) conducted a large-scale study (n 756) subjects,
496 COVID-19 positives and 260 negatives to compare the diag-
ﬁ nostic performance of an AI system with that of ve radiologists. It
was found that the AI system achieved high sensitivity (94%),
ﬁ speci city (95.47%) and diagnostic accuracy, which was comparable
69 to that of experienced radiologists (94.7% sensitivity). This par-
ﬁ allels with the ndings of Chen et al. (2020), who found similar
performance between a COVID-19 diagnosis system and an expert
radiologist; however, it is important to note that the AI system in
¼ this study was validated based upon a small dataset (n 19
80 ﬁ con rmed COVID-19 patients) and one radiologist. It was found
ﬁ that high classi cation results were achieved for coronavirus versus
non-coronavirus patients with 98.2% sensitivity and 92.2% speci-
81 ﬁ city. A similar result was reported by Xu et al. (2020); however, it
is interesting to note that the diagnostic certainty of the AI system
82 ﬁ was evaluated by creating con dence scores of these forecasts. A
deep learning approach can assist radiologists in diagnosing
COVID-19 and can automatically extract lesions within CT images,
e 65 , 83 86
as indicated by Song et al. (2020) and Bai et al. (2020). Bai
et al. (2020) indicated that the DL tool achieved a prediction area
$ under curve (AUC) of 0 938 by combining the clinical data and the
83 CT data.
AI systems, especially deep learning, have been proposed to
process and analyse medical imaging data such as chest CT to assist
radiologists and physicians to improve diagnosis performance. The
AI offers radiologists an opportunity to save time and maximise
87 productivity especially when required to examine a lot of cases.
Bai et al. (2020) assessed the performance of radiologists in
88 differentiating COVID-19 from other viral pneumonia on chest CT.
ﬁ It was found that radiologists achieved high speci city and mod-
erate sensitivity in distinguishing COVID-19 from other viral
pneumonia on chest CT. A further interesting study was conducted
by Bai et al. (2020) to assess radiologists' performance with and
without AI assistance in distinguishing coronavirus versus non-
coronavirus patients. The authors found that radiologists attained
ﬁ a higher accuracy (90%), sensitivity (88%) and speci city (91%) with
89 AI assistance. This suggests the potential role for the AI system to
ﬂ improve radiologists' routine work ow and diagnostic outcomes
related to COVID-19. It is worth noting that all the above studies
were retrospective, and prospective studies might be required to
’ further validate AI system in real time to assist physicians
diagnosis.
As can be seen, AI systems can be used in conjunction with chest
CT images and patient history (age, gender, clinical information,
blood test, symptoms and possible contact with infected people) to
improve the detection of the infection. The AI systems helps to
segment the exact infected area of the patient's lung from the chest
CT and quantify the volume with respect to the total volume of the
28 lung. This information might guide the physician in decision-
making related to treatment options. The AI system can offer a
second opinion to the physician in patients who had normal chest
ﬁ ﬁ CT or those showing non-speci c ndings, in order to achieve high
ﬁ sensitivity, speci city and accuracy in COVID-19 diagnosis and
management.
685

W. Alsharif and A. Qurashi
The above studies indicate that AI systems could be used to
screen and diagnose quickly a great volume of patients with sus-
pected COVID-19, which could lead to accurate discrimination be-
tween bacterial pneumonia and viral pneumonia (COVID-19) and
decrease unnecessary delays. However, radiologists who are not
familiar with such systems may face challenges in getting used to
them, which might be problematic because COVID-19 is spreading
rapidly. In addition, as most deep learning systems require experts
to annotate the lesions in the CT images for disease detection, this
will require time and effort from radiologists, which might be
considered a big challenge due to the current radiologist shortages
90 in some countries. Naude (2020) indicate that the use of AI sys-
tems are impeded by a lack of data, and by too much data. These
limitations require a careful balance between data privacy and
e public health, and rigorous human AI interface. It is unlikely that
these will be tackled in the current time; more diagnostic data
40 needs to be gathered to train AI and save lives. The topic of the
role of AI in the diagnosis and management of COVID-19 remains
open for further investigation.
Conclusion
This review of the available literature on COVID-19 provides
insights into the value of CT scan in diagnosing and controlling this
infection. Although in some studies chest CT scans have shown high
sensitivity in diagnosing COVID-19 compared to RT-PCR tests, chest
ﬁ CT scans alone are not suf cient to detect COVID-19 and can be
useful complement to other tools for diagnosing patients with
COVID-19 and tracking their prognosis. CT scans can be used as a
staging tool to assess the complications of COVID-19 on patients'
ﬁ lungs. The CT ndings for patients with COVID-19 show that the
infection has mixed and diverse features. The presence of GGO with
single or multiple lesions suggests that the disease is in an early
stage, while bilateral multifocal consolidation can be seen in an
advanced stage. As COVID-19 has similar manifestations to other
pneumonia diseases, several AI systems have been proposed and
developed in order to differentiate COVID-19 from other pneu-
monia diseases.
